discussion.p: uses the word "native" in several places, but doesn't define it. What is a "native duration"?
discussion.blockquote: The standard uses "native" in several places without defining it (e.g. ). It is meant to mean "that which is defined by the facility", or something along those lines. In this case it refers to the nested time_point and duration types of the clock. Better wording is welcome.
Move to Open pending proposed wording from Pete.

blockquote.blockquote: Precondition: If the tick period of rel_time is not exactly convertible to the native tick period, the duration shall be rounded up to the nearest native tick period.
blockquote.p: I would prefer to see that adapted as well. Following the same style as the proposed resolution I come up with
blockquote.blockquote: Precondition: If the tick period of rel_time is not exactly convertible to the native tick period of the execution environment, the duration shall be rounded up to the nearest native tick period of the execution environment.

discussion.blockquote: Moved to Tentatively Ready with revised wording from Howard Hinnant after 5 positive votes on c++std-lib.

blockquote.p: 1 A clock is a bundle consisting of a native duration, a native time_point, and a function now() to get the current time_point. The origin of the clock's time_point is referred to as the clock's epoch. A clock shall meet the requirements in Table 56.

tr.td: An arithmetic type or a class emulating an arithmetic type
The representation type of the native C1::duration. and time_point.
The native duration type of the clock.
The native time_point type of the clock. C1 and C2 shall refer to the same epoch.
